facts: The ancient Olympic Games began in Olympia, Greece, around 776 BCE and were held to honor the god Zeus.
The modern Olympic Games were restarted in 1896 in Athens, Greece, thanks to French organizer Pierre de Coubertin.
The Olympic symbol has five interlocking rings that represent the connection of athletes from around the world.
At the Ancient Olympics, only free Greek men could compete, and many events were run in the nude.
The Olympic torch relay is a modern tradition that started at the 1936 Berlin Olympics and ends with the lighting of the cauldron.
Olympic gold medals are mostly silver, with a thin layer of gold on the outside.
The Olympic motto is Latin—'Citius, Altius, Fortius'—which means 'Faster, Higher, Stronger.'
